question: What is the W.E.B Dubois <image 1>?
options: ['Says the organization of society (stratiLcations based on class, ethnicity, gender, age, etc.) and the changes in society can be explained by the conSicts inherent to social relations.', 'Is the economic system that is directed at earning a proLt for a few, selling the proLts to many people, and keeping workers wages low in order to increase proLts', 'Is a theory that focuses on the social structures that shape society as a whole. It sees society as a complex system whose parts work together to maintain stability and to promote solidarity.', 'Refers to the particular experience of African Americans where in which they are forced to see themselves their status as citizens who are never able to escape identiLcation based on the color of their skin']
description:
The image shows the cover of a book titled "Double-Consciousness and the Rhetoric of Barack Obama: The Price and Promise of Citizenship" by Robert E. Terrill. The title is prominently displayed in large font, with "Double-Consciousness" split into two colors—blue and red—to emphasize the concept of duality. The subtitle, "and the Rhetoric of Barack Obama," is written in smaller text below the main title. Further down, the phrase "The Price and Promise of Citizenship" appears in a slightly larger font than the subtitle but smaller than the main title. At the bottom of the cover, the author's name, "Robert E. Terrill," is clearly printed. The background of the cover is plain white, with a vertical gray shadow running down the center, dividing the text into two halves. The design suggests a focus on the concept of double-consciousness, particularly in relation to Barack Obama's rhetoric and its implications for citizenship. 

This description highlights the central theme of "double-consciousness," which aligns with option D in the question, referring to the particular experience of African Americans where they are forced to see themselves through the lens of their status as citizens while also being identified by the color of their skin.
